results.title: Geyser melodies
results.creator_credit: Guy Haselton and Guy O Hasleton Productions
results.brief_description: The world’s greatest display of geysers and hot springs in Yellowstone National Park in North America. Shown as being closely akin to nature’s most awesome spectacle - volcanoes. Designed to promote a better understanding of the earth’s beginnings and to show the artistry of nature in one of its most spectacular forms.

results.title: Getting your act together!
results.creator_credit: Sue Johnston and Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology. Communication Services Unit. Television Studios
results.brief_description: Feeling lost and alone on a large tertiary campus is not an uncommon feeling among new students. Students talk about their expectations, and experiences of tertiary education. Advice is given on finance, housing, study skills and personal support.

results.title: Getting through
results.brief_description: Examines the question of whether public health authorities are getting through the message of smoking’s dangers. Two major obstacles are that smoking has been socially acceptable for 400 years, and that the effects of smoking are so long delayed “you don’t know in the morning that young get lung cancer in the afternoon”. Consternates on Charlie, a typical teenage smoker and his girlfriend, Judy, with narration by Burt Lancaster.

results.title: Getting the message
results.brief_description: The mass media are being studied by scholars today more closely than ever before. Media study has been lagging behind but it is suggested that teaching at school level may help. This film shows what is being done in Tasmanian schools today with the critical study of news media and the study of film and television as an art form. It is one of the few states in Australia with a compulsory course in mass media as an examination subject in all secondary schools. The aim - to make students grow into discriminating adults.

results.title: Getting the job: personal experiences with selection panels
results.creator_credit: Lily Steiner and Victoria. Ministry of Education. Film, Television and Audio Unit
results.brief_description: Focuses on the strategies women employ in order to maximise their chances in job applications. 1. Getting the job. Details the strategies that can be used in job applications as well as techniques to help ensure a successful interview. Women who have been successful in obtaining positions talk about their experiences in applying for jobs. 2 Personal Experiences with Selection Panels. Several women who have been successful in obtaining positions within the Ministry of Education give advice on their experiences in applying for jobs.

results.title: Getting into jeans
results.creator_credit: Paul Wingate, Chris Strange, Ross D Wylie and AVCOM Productions
results.brief_description: Graeme (Shirley) Strachan presents an overview of the production of a pair of jeans from the beginning of the design process through to the sale to the customer. Shows the function of computers in laying out pattern pieces to the material available, the machinist at work, and the activity of wholesalers and retailers.

results.title: Getting down to earth
results.creator_credit: Denver Sutton, Richard Reinhardt, William Bronson and Wine Advisory Board
results.brief_description: The goddess Daphne decends to California (with backup help from Bacchus) to help restaurant staff promote and sell more wine with meals. Emphasizes effective presentation of wines and the virtues of California wines.

results.title: Getting around in French
results.creator_credit: Harry Mehlman and Educational TV Services
results.brief_description: Students from Assumption College, Kilmore and Nunawading HIgh School are shown in a number of situations using French language skills they have acquired from the Eclair French language course. Various situations are depicted and the program concludes with students giving their opinions on the Eclair course of study.

results.title: Get wet again
results.brief_description: More fun with Jonathan Coleman. In this program his nervous “brother” Terry learns to swim - with the assistance of Lisa Forrest. The emphasis is on feeling at ease in the water and includes activities such as blowing bubbles, floating, basic swimming and rescue.
